Birmingham) but as it has the support of the Board of Trade and the Treasury it is put forward for approval of the Cabinet in accordance with the arrangements applicable to Bills supported by Departments but left to Private Members to introduce.Under the existing law all imported ornamental foreign plate must he assayed and marked in the same way as plate made in Great Britain, and must not be offered for sale unless it is so marker1, hut the Customs Amendment Act of 1842 granted exemption from hall-marking to foreign plate manufactured "before 1800.The present Bill is drawn to extend this exemption from hall-marking to all imported foreign plate manufactured more than 100 years before the date of importation, or the date of sale as the case may he. This would bring the matter into line with Section 8 of the Finance Act, 1926, under which Customs duties are not chargeable on goods manufactured or produced more than 100 years before the date of importation. 9 9 9Q hi MThe Bill, which has "been drafted "by Parliamentary Counsel, has the hacking of the trade and has the support of the Board of Trade and the Board of Customs and Excise.The approval of the Cabinet in principle is sought, subject to detailed examination of the Bill "by the Home Affairs Committee.(Initialled) J.S.Treasury Chambers, S.W. 1, 20th October, 1938.
